Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling and Characterization of Transition Joints Made by Friction Surfacing Based Additive Manufacturing (FSAM)

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this collaborative study is to demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of modeling and control of Friction Surfacing-based Additive Manufacturing by creating a functionally graded, multi-layered weld transition joint between chrome moly steel (T91) and austenitic stainless steel (AISI316). The research approach will be to apply various nickel based alloy layers by friction surfacing, creating a smooth and gradual transition in physical and metallurgical properties to improve their creep life. The experimental program involves stress rupture and creep-fatigue tests to assess the creep behavior of the transition joints. The research approach for in-situ finite element modeling involves development of fine-scale crystal plasticity and homogenized anisotropic continuum plasticity models, which will help in obtaining the optimized process parameters for the fabrication of components using Friction Surfacing-based Additive Manufacturing.

If successful, this research will aid the accelerated deployment of T91 and AISI316 weld transitional joints for structures in emerging initiatives including boiler, nuclear and clean energy concepts. Through the finite element model development, not only can T91/316 joints be made, but a basic modeling and manufacturing infrastructure will be developed that can be applied to any application where transitional joints are needed between hard-to-process materials and/or materials where fusion welding produces undesirable intermetallic formation. The successful completion of this research will enable higher-temperature power plants to generate power 1) at lower cost 2) with lower greenhouse gas emissions and 3) in larger quantities resulting in a better quality of life. The results will also help make it possible to manufacture better performing and optimized components in a host of other engineering industries. The educational objectives of the proposal will focus on training of post-doctoral researchers, graduate and undergraduate students. Advanced Surface Technology course will be developed which will expose the students to the state-of-the-art advances in manufacturing technologies.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

– NSF Award# 1234079

Project Title: Collaborative Research: Modeling and Characterization of Transition Joints Made by Friction Surfacing Based Additive Manufacturing (FSAM)

Recipient Organizations: University of Utah and University of Louisville

Project/Grant Period: 08/01/2012 – 07/31/15

PIs and Co-PIs: Manoranjan Misra  and Prasad Rao Kalvala (University of Utah) and Brent Stucker and Deepankar Pal (University of Louisville)

The study was aimed to understand the creep degradation mechanisms of dissimilar metal welds between modified 9Cr-1Mo steel (P91) and austenitic stainless steels applicable for high temperature energy applications  and offer solutions to improve their creep resistance. Currently used Cr-Mo and stainless steel weld joints are prone to premature failures causing huge loss of money. Improvement of their creep life will decrease the cost of producing electricity which will benefit public at large and help decrease environmental degradation.  Different Ni-based interlayers with gradual change in coefficient of thermal expansions (CTE) are deposited between these two dissimilar metals using solid state welding processes. The study showed the importance of having relatively high Ni content of the interlayers in reducing carbon diffusion between the two metals in improving the creep rupture of weld transition joints. The study also proposed creep mechanisms for the studied weld transition joints.

Main outcomes of the project are the  understanding of creep deformation mechanism of transition weld joints with Ni-alloy interlayers and understanding the role of carbon diffusion across weld interface at P91 as affected by the Ni-content of interlayers. Salient outcomes of the study are as follows:

  • Improved rupture life of 3 layer weld transition joint was found to be  due to gradual change in CTE values than single layer weld transition joint
  • Relatively higher Ni content of the interlayers helped  in reducing carbon diffusion from P91 steel to austenitic stainless steel and improved the creep rupture resistance of weld transition joints
  • Creep rate controlling mechanism proposed  in these transition joints is high temperature climb of edge dislocations
  • Dissolution of lath martensite in the HAZ of P91 is attributed to precipitation of carbon in the form of carbides along the grain boundaries
  • Based on ease of fabrication and resultant larger grain size after post weld heat treatment, Friction welding method was found to be  useful  compared to friction surfacing method to develop interlayers between dissimilar metals.

The intellectual merit of this joint effort between the University of Utah and University of Louisville was  two fold. First, to contain the problem of carbon diffusion between P91 and AISI 304/316 steels such that carbon diffusion doesn’t occur and second, to exhibit the feasibility of friction surfacing and friction welding as additive manufacturing techniques in a multilayered fashion. The results of the work have established the significant understanding of the mechanisms of failure of these dissimilar metal weld joints and provided practical methods to improve their creep life. A numerical model has been formulated for hot deformation during friction assisted additive manufacturing of interlayer buttons which ease the transition from P91 to AISI304 using interlayer Inconel alloys with intermediate coefficients of thermal expansion. Moreover, the methods for computing residual stresses and distortions of this additive manufacturing technique provide with methods which could be used in other metal melting based AM technologies as well such as Selective Laser Melting and Electron Beam Melting.

The broader impacts include training of students. Two  researchers got benefitted from this project apart from PI/Co-PIs at both the Universities. One student earned his doctoral degree (thesis in communication) and another  learnt the aspect of possibility to perform additive manufacturing using Friction surfacing. A course on Selected Topics in Metallurgy with a specific reference to Weld Surface Engineering was taught. The  scope of the project was explained and increased the awareness about friction surfaced additive manufacturing to teachers and students at the University. A one day workshop was conducted by one of the Co-PIs on ‘Understanding Modeling and Simulation of Additive Manufacturing Processes’ organized by the AMC (Additive Manufacturing Consortium) and lead organizer for a 4.5 day long course on ‘Simulation of Additive Manufacturing’ organized by the TMS (The Minerals, Metals and Materials Society).

Modified by: Prasad Rao Kalvala
